entry.title: Re: (Custom) Idoc: issue when changing data type of a field
entry.content:
You have to remember what an IDoc is and how it is stored. Each segment is effectively a data container with the data of the segment stored in EDID4-SDATA with each field being located within a specific offset of the overall data container.  If you lengthen one field then you have stretched its contents to a space previously contained by some other data element.  Hence, if you want to lengthen a field what you are in effect doing is creating a new IDoc version, which is how you would manage that from a technical point of view without affecting older IDocs.

 

Regards,

Ryan Crosby

entry.content:
Hi @BabuSathya Thank you for your suggestions. I am still facing Privilege error while creating remote system in Datasphere using live tunnel connection for my SAP BW/4 2023 SP05 system. Below are the checks I performed -

* I tested the BW/4HANA end points and they are working fine.

* I checked the BW Metadata Extraction service via transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN and all the below mentioned services and service groups are added in my BW/4 system.

* I checked the cloud connector and below resources are added for my BW/4 system -

sap/bc/http/sap/bw4/v1/system/information
sap/opu/odata4/sap - Path & All sub-paths
/sap/opu/odata4/sap/rv_i_dwc_area_tree_sb/ - Path and all sub-paths
/sap/opu/odata4/sap/rv_c_dwc_obj_header/ - Path and all sub-paths
/sap/opu/odata4/sap/rv_i_dwc_details_sb/ - Path and all sub-paths

* I tried to install SAP note 3570254 but its showing me 'Not relevant' for my BW/4 system hence I installed latest SAP note 3601550 which installed successfully.

Thanks & Regards, Puneet

entry.title: Re: Developer Extensibility Public Cloud - QR code
entry.content:
Hello @lvbarat 

Adobe Forms in S/4HANA Public Cloud cannot convert a plain QR string into a QR image on its own. Even though you receive the QR string (like from the GST portal), you need to:

  • Convert that string into a QR code image (PNG or BMP).
  • Base64-encode the image.
  • Pass the Base64 string to the form XML so it can be displayed as an embedded image.

Thatâ€™s how SAP expects QR codes to be handled in custom forms.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Data replication framework (DRF) setup in S4 public c...
entry.content:
Hello @FlorisBoon 

Thereâ€™s no specific Best Practice scope item for DRF master data replication from SAP S/4HANA Public cloud Edition to decentralised EWM, but itâ€™s fully supported.

Steps to follow,

  • Use Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0247 for Product and Business Partner replication.
  • Trigger replication via Replicate by Replication Model App DRF_ADHOC_REPLICATION ()
  • Set up filtering and key mapping as needed (to handle old prefixes).
  • Monitor errors using Application Log or Application Logs-App ID F1487

Basic Integration with SAP Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM)

Migrating On-Premises Connectivity from Neo Environment to Cloud Foundry Environment

Data Replication Framework

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: A question on SAP Marketing Cloud Coupons (and Offers)
entry.content:
Hello marketers experts!

We are starting to work with Offers and Coupons in SAP Marketing Cloud at my organization.

Since our coupons are generated by an external system, we mass upload them into Marketing Cloud through the "Manage Coupons" app. The coupon type and relationship type combination that best suits us is "Multiple Coupon Codes and Contact Assigned Dynamically"

Later, we create an Offer and we assign a target group to that Offer (because of the eligibility criteria).  That Static Target Group is the same that receives the campaign at the end. And we include the coupon cod on the email content we send in that campaign. We follow this process (Solved: Sending coupon via email in SAP Marketing Cloud - SAP Community)

After sending the email campaign with the offer code, I am requested to send the contact ID and the coupon cod that contact received through our email campaign, before the contact redeems it. Immediately after the campaign was sent or the coupon was assigned.

I tried visualizing that data through the Browse Interaction Data but it was not possible to see them from the standard view (I tried to add "coupon cod e" and wasn't there). I did see the coupon cod e assigned to a particular contact though, there at Browse Contact Interaction Data, I went inside each outbound email interaction and see the Offer and Coupon Section and there it was the coupon cod e assigned to the contact. Still, to do that for a lot of contacts is not efficient.

From the Analytics and Report Gallery Offer reports the coupons are not visible, I could just see offers. (We don't have SAC either)

I understand that SAP Marketing Cloud assigns the coupon codes randomly to the contacts present in the target group. And I want to mass extract that assignation of contact ID (or email ID, or interaction ID) and coupon cod assigned. Is that possible?

entry.title: Re: View payment proposal that was created using â€˜Automat...
entry.content: I had the same question as Urszula above. The two answers did not provide the link to the list of proposed or blocked payments. entry.title: Re: G/L OIM issue
entry.content:
Hello @SAM123567 ,

You cannot simply deactivate and reactivate OIM without cleansing the BSIS,BSAS and other such tables. SAP locks the account if inconsistencies are found in the line item and index tables.

1. If you really want to reset OIM from scratch, deactivate OIM using transaction FAGL_ACTIVATE_OP. Clean index tables manually or via program RFSEPA03 (consult SAP note first). Delete entries in BSIS/BSAS for that account before reactivation. Then re-activate OIM with the correct switch-on date.
2. Another option is to run transaction SE38, and execute program RFSEPA01 (check/repair open item management inconsistencies). It compares BSIS/BSAS with BSEG. If inconsistencies are found, you may be able to correct them with RFSEPA02 (use carefully in non-prod first!). This is "Consulting Solution" - use with extreme caution. 

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Business Partner Role for Manufacturer
entry.content:
Hello @KeLaw,

Try below two options and let me know.

1.Create Manufacturer BPs Without a Supplier Role.Create a new BP without assigning any purchasing-related roles like FLVN00 or FLVN01. These BPs will act as manufacturers only and will not appear in supplier-related F4 helps, ensuring a clear separation. Assign only the "000000 â€“ General Role" or optionally, create a custom BP role (non-transactional).
2. Assign Manufacturer to Material Master. In the â€œPurchasingâ€ view of the Material Master, Field: Manufacturer (MFRNR). Use the F4 help to select from existing BPs (youâ€™ll see all BPs, so naming or grouping becomes important)

Appreciate your feedback.

entry.title: Re: Setup a new ledger in the year of brown field conversion
entry.content:
Hello @HTO ,

1. Add the tax ledger after the first fiscal year post-conversion. This is SAPâ€™s recommended approach. Complete the S/4HANA brownfield conversion with only the HGB ledger. Start the tax ledger in the next fiscal year (e.g., FY 2026).
2. Other option is use extension Ledger temporarily, only for simulation. SAP allows extension ledgers, which do not store actual transactional data, but overlay adjustments on top of a base ledger. You can create an extension ledger for tax view. Post adjustment entries manually (or via BADI) that simulate tax effects. Use this for reporting only, not legal postings.  Please note - extension ledgers cannot be used for Asset Accounting or depreciation calculationsâ€”theyâ€™re for reporting only.

However, consult SAP for appropriate approach.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Tax id rule setting in SAP (Taiwan)
entry.content:
Hello @SM1970 ,

In Taiwan, companies are legally required to validate Tax ID (VAT Registration Number) structure. I guess your are referring to same only. If that's the case then, enable tax number categories. For BP or customer/vendor tax ID setup, Go to OY17: Define tax number categories. Example: TW â€“ VAT Reg. No. Now, go to OY18: Assign tax number categories to country (TW).


Secondly, maintain validation rule using user exit or BADI (BADI_FITV_SUBSTITUTE)
SAP does not natively validate Taiwan VAT ID logic (e.g., checksum). You can implement a custom validation via: User Exit EXIT_SAPMF02K_001 (Vendor Master validation). BADI or implicit enhancement in standard function.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: inventory audit report, with added 2-column input dat...
entry.content:
Hello @totommyng ,

Here is a complete ABAP report template for SAP ECC to generate an Inventory Audit Report with the following fields:

-Material (Item)
-Description
-Quantity (Today)
-Quantity (Cumulative)
-Value (Today)
-Value (Cumulative)
-Cost/Unit Today
-Cost/Unit (Old Date)
-Cost Variance (Absolute and %)

-Uses MSEG, MKPF, MARA, MAKT tables.
-Uses two date parameters: current date and comparison date.

I got the sample script from my friend.

This is a classical ABAP report with ALV output.
If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

ABAP CODE is as follow:-

REPORT zinventory_audit_report.

TABLES: mara, makt, mseg, mkpf.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_output,
matnr TYPE matnr,
maktx TYPE maktx,
qty_today TYPE menge_d,
qty_cum TYPE menge_d,
val_today TYPE dmbtr,
val_cum TYPE dmbtr,
cpu_today TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
cpu_old TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
var_abs TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
var_pct TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
END OF ty_output.

DATA: it_output TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_output,
wa_output TYPE ty_output.

DATA: lt_mseg TYPE TABLE OF mseg,
lt_mkpf TYPE TABLE OF mkpf,
lt_mara TYPE TABLE OF mara,
lt_makt TYPE TABLE OF makt.

DATA: lv_qty_today TYPE menge_d,
lv_qty_cum TYPE menge_d,
lv_val_today TYPE dmbtr,
lv_val_cum TYPE dmbtr,
lv_cpu_today TYPE p DECIMALS 2,
lv_cpu_old TYPE p DECIMALS 2.

PARAMETERS: p_date_curr TYPE budat OBLIGATORY DEFAULT sy-datum,
p_date_old TYPE budat OBLIGATORY.

SELECT-OPTIONS: s_matnr FOR mara-matnr.

START-OF-SELECTION.

SELECT * FROM mseg INTO TABLE lt_mseg
WHERE matnr IN s_matnr
AND bwart IN ('101', '102', '561', '562').

IF lt_mseg IS INITIAL.
MESSAGE 'No material movements found.' TYPE 'I'.
EXIT.
ENDIF.

LOOP AT lt_mseg INTO DATA(ls_mseg).
SELECT SINGLE * FROM mkpf INTO DATA(ls_mkpf)
WHERE mblnr = ls_mseg-mblnr
AND mjahr = ls_mseg-mjahr.

IF sy-subrc <> 0.
CONTINUE.
ENDIF.

CLEAR: lv_qty_today, lv_qty_cum, lv_val_today, lv_val_cum, lv_cpu_today, lv_cpu_old.

" Cumulative values
SELECT SUM( menge ) INTO lv_qty_cum
FROM mseg
WHERE matnr = ls_mseg-matnr
AND bwart IN ('101','102','561','562').

SELECT SUM( dmbtr ) INTO lv_val_cum
FROM mseg
WHERE matnr = ls_mseg-matnr
AND bwart IN ('101','102','561','562').

" Today's values
SELECT SUM( menge ) INTO lv_qty_today
FROM mseg AS m
INNER JOIN mkpf AS k ON m~mblnr = k~mblnr AND m~mjahr = k~mjahr
WHERE m~matnr = ls_mseg-matnr
AND k~budat = p_date_curr
AND m~bwart IN ('101','102','561','562').

SELECT SUM( dmbtr ) INTO lv_val_today
FROM mseg AS m
INNER JOIN mkpf AS k ON m~mblnr = k~mblnr AND m~mjahr = k~mjahr
WHERE m~matnr = ls_mseg-matnr
AND k~budat = p_date_curr
AND m~bwart IN ('101','102','561','562').

" Compute CPU today
IF lv_qty_today <> 0.
lv_cpu_today = lv_val_today / lv_qty_today.
ENDIF.

" Old Date CPU
SELECT SUM( menge ) AS qty, SUM( dmbtr ) AS val INTO @DATA(ls_old)
FROM mseg AS m
INNER JOIN mkpf AS k ON m~mblnr = k~mblnr AND m~mjahr = k~mjahr
WHERE m~matnr = @ls_mseg-matnr
AND k~budat = @p_date_old
AND m~bwart IN ('101','102','561','562').

IF ls_old-qty <> 0.
lv_cpu_old = ls_old-val / ls_old-qty.
ENDIF.

" Fill output
wa_output-matnr = ls_mseg-matnr.
SELECT SINGLE maktx INTO wa_output-maktx FROM makt
WHERE matnr = ls_mseg-matnr AND spras = 'E'.

wa_output-qty_today = lv_qty_today.
wa_output-qty_cum = lv_qty_cum.
wa_output-val_today = lv_val_today.
wa_output-val_cum = lv_val_cum.
wa_output-cpu_today = lv_cpu_today.
wa_output-cpu_old = lv_cpu_old.
wa_output-var_abs = lv_cpu_today - lv_cpu_old.

IF lv_cpu_old <> 0.
wa_output-var_pct = ( lv_cpu_today - lv_cpu_old ) / lv_cpu_old * 100.
ENDIF.

APPEND wa_output TO it_output.
CLEAR wa_output.
ENDLOOP.

IF it_output IS INITIAL.
MESSAGE 'No data found for selection.' TYPE 'I'.
EXIT.
ENDIF.

" Display with ALV
CALL FUNCTION 'REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY'
EXPORTING
i_structure_name = 'TY_OUTPUT'
TABLES
t_outtab = it_output.

entry.title: Re: Activating the Status Based import in ChaRM
entry.content:
Hi All,

As of now we are performing the selective import every Friday into PRE-PRD systems via tasklist after cab approval. And also if  a user comes with a request to import the CD to PRE-PRD on any given day (not a emergency transport) we are doing it manually via task list. 

But going forward, we want to move through the automatic import job where there's no manual intervention in performing the imports via ChaRM. I understand that to achieve this, we need to change the import strategy to "Status Dependent import" and schedule the import job periodically to run on (eg: Friday-once in a week at specified time) via a specific task list.

On every Friday, we get a list of CD's to be moved to Pre-PRD and in that there are few CD's  which are interdependent with each other. ie a user want's to import his  / her CD's in sequence (CD#1 and then, CD#2 and CD#3...).

My questions:

1. If we scheduled the import job (with Status dependent import) to run weekly once on specific time, how the import interdependent CD's (CD#1 and then, CD#2 and CD#3...) will be handled? Does the auto import job is capable enough to identify the sequence of CD's (CD#1 and then, CD#2 and CD#3...) to be imported in sequence?

2. How to handle the CD(s) when a user(s) comes with their request to import one or two specific CD's on any given day (eg: Tuesday / Wednesday) and can not wait until Friday (as the auto import job is scheduled to run). I understand that when import strategy is  selected as "Status dependent Import" , there's no option to select the specific CD to import ( selective import). Is it still recommended to go with import strategy "Status dependent import" and inform the users to wait until next auto import job (ie Friday)?

3. Just to let you know that there no specific roles assigned to the system Type / system name / client.  we have given * for all the system type / system name / client / Roles in SPRO -> Specify import Transport request import strategy->import strategy view page.

 

So far we have been performing selective  import via task list in PRE-PRD and PRD. 

Please let me know what are the implications for the above mentioned approach if  we change the import strategy to "Status dependent import" from "Import with selection Popup" .

Regards,

Satish

in Public Cloud you cannot get exactly the same result as in ECC. But you could do the following.

entry.title: Best Custom Packaging Company in USA in 2025?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I wanted to share a quick experience and also get your input on something a bit outside the typical SAP discussionâ€”but still very relevant to anyone working with outbound logistics and packaging integration in EWM.

This year, we started working with a U.S.-based company called Packaging Unit to manage our custom boxes and packaging needs. They offer tailored packaging solutions, and what really stood out to me was their speed, flexibility with custom sizes, and how easy it was to get everything branded exactly the way we needed.

Weâ€™ve been exploring deeper integration between SAP EWM and their automated packaging workflowsâ€”especially around auto-creating packaging materials and syncing with outbound deliveries. So far, it's been a solid experience, and it has helped streamline part of our fulfillment process.

That said, Iâ€™m curious:

  • Has anyone else here worked with Packaging Unit or a similar provider?

  • Are you integrating custom packaging vendors directly with SAP EWM or ERP?

  • Any tips or tools youâ€™ve found helpful in managing external packaging data (like dimensions, materials, or branding) inside SAP?

Would love to hear how others in the community are approaching this, especially with growing eCommerce demands and the push toward branded, sustainable packaging.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, thatâ€™s all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAPâ€™s commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.
